page.title: 02The Great Northern Railway
page.content:
In 1850, the Great Northern Railway (G.N.R.) opened its main line from Maiden Lane, near the present terminus of Kings Cross in London to Peterborough. The southern extension to Kings Cross was opened in 1852. In stages, the G.N.R entended and reached Leeds and York, connecting with the North Eastern Railway to give access to Newcastle and Edinburgh. This is still one of the main lines in the British railway system.
The station at Sandy was opened in 1850 and, as well as offering easy access to passengers to London allowed the local farmers and market gardeners the ability to easily send their produce to large markets. The growth of the market gardening in the area owes much to the railway.
